sub_topic: Prove that the symmetric difference of two sets is not commutative with respect to intersection.
message_2:
The symmetric difference (Δ) of two sets is the set of elements which are in either of the sets but not in their intersection. Since (A∩B) and (B∩A) are the same set (the intersection of A and B), their symmetric difference will be an empty set.

First, let's find the intersection of A and B:

A∩B = {2, 3, 4}

Now, let's find the symmetric difference between (A∩B) and (B∩A):

(A∩B)Δ(B∩A) = {x: x ∈ (A∩B) or x ∈ (B∩A), but not both}

Since (A∩B) and (B∩A) are the same set, there are no elements that are in one set but not the other. Therefore, the symmetric difference is an empty set:

(A∩B)Δ(B∩A) = ∅
